Boyd's Key West Campground - Key West, FL Owner Log In List My Campground Campground Management Solutions Rent an RV Traveler Log In Help Create Account Owner Owner Log In List My Campground Campground Management Solutions Traveler Rent an RV Traveler Log In Help Create Account Home Florida Campgrounds Key West Campgrounds Boyd's Key West Campground Boyd's Key West Campground (7) Reviews Claim my Campground Save to Favorites Travelers Booked These Nearby (7) Photos + Videos Overview Rates Map (7) Reviews Overview 6401 Maloney Avenue, Key West, FL, 33040 Boyd's Key West Campground is located on the breathtaking island of Key West, Florida and is an amazing spot for a fun outdoor vacation. With wide, open spaces, fresh air and plenty of attractions and southern hospitality, you'll want to come back year after year! Activities and Amenities Campers can look forward to onsite activities to keep every member of the group engaged and having fun. There's opportunities for kayaking, swimming, surfing, beach volleyball, picnicking, stand-up paddle boarding, snorkeling, fishing, cruising, birding and scenic viewing. Plus, there's plenty of opportunities for sunset viewing and stargazing. Amenities at the park include: oceanfront sites, dump station, dishwashing station, WIFI, laundry facilities, bath houses, boating docks, 30/50 amp sites, full hook up sites and a game room. Attractions RVers can take advantage of a number of attractions just beyond the campground, including: - Dry Tortugas National Park - Southernmost point buoy - Ernest Hemingway House - Fort Zachary Taylor Historic State Park - Key West Butterfly and Nature Conservatory - Duval Street for great shopping, dining and night time entertainment - Smathers Beach - Key West lighthouse Hope to see you at the Boyd's Key West Campground for your next Key West camping trip! Last Updated: 11/15/2024 Rates RV Sites For most accurate rates according to the time of year, please visit the campground website: https://www.boydscampground.com/ Options Starting Daily Starting Weekly Starting Monthly INLAND SITE RATES Full Hookup $99.00 INLAND SITE RATES Water &Electric $77.00 Waterfront Site Rates Full Hook Up - Dockside Waterfront View $121.00 Waterfront Site Rates Full Hook Up - Waterfront View $127.00 Tent Sites Options Starting Daily Starting Weekly Starting Monthly Tents INLAND SITE RATES $61.00 Tents WATERFRONT SITES RATES $71.00 Rules Pet Rules 1.	We are animal lovers, very fond of pets and appreciate the fact that people recognize their pets to be an integral part of their family. However, no aggressive pets or any that have previously bitten or attacked people or pets are allowed. Additionally, breeds of dogs which are by nature, history, or perception aggressive, such as Pit Bulls, Rottweilers, Doberman Pincers, Chows, German Shepherds, and Wolf Hybrids, are not permitted.
2.	Owners must pick up after their pets.
3.	All pets must be kept on a leash and under the owner's control at all times.
4.	Pets are not allowed in the pool area or any park building, including restrooms and showers.
5.	Owners are responsible for their pet's behavior.
6.	If you leave, please take your pets with you. Pets may not be left unattended.
7.	If your pet is creating a problem, the management will require that the owner take appropriate action. Vehicle Restrictions 1.	All persons must have a valid drivers license to drive. Children should NEVER be allowed to drive any motorized vehicle in the campground.
2.	Vehicles must have proper lights for driving at night and follow manufacturer's specifications for seating capacity.
3.	Remove keys from all motorized vehicles when not in use.
4.	Motorized scooters, golf carts, ATV's SHOULD NOT be used for joyriding. These vehicles are not toys and should only be used for transportation. General Policies 1.	Campground fees are payable at registration. Checkout time is 11:00am. Please checkout or re-register before 11:00am.
2.	Quiet Hours 11:00pm-7:00am are strictly enforced.
3.	All visitors must check-in and out with office and leave the campground by 11:00 pm. Overnight visitors/vehicles must be registered and paid for in advance.
4.	Children and teenagers must be on their site under parental supervision by 10:00pm.
5.	Clean fish at the fish cleaning station only. No fish remains in dumpster.
6.	Fresh water is scarce. Please check your hose connections for leaks. We turn off water leaks. Please fix to eliminate leaks before turning water back on.
7.	Boat washing at boat ramp only.
8.	Discharging and possession of firearms or fireworks is strictly forbidden.
9.	Rules pertaining to the use of the pool are posted. Swim at your own risk.
10.	Only one recreational vehicle or one tent per site.
11.	Limit 4 adults per site, including visitors.
12.	Keep campsites free of debris. Dispose of trash in the nearest dumpster.
13.	Only small safe campfires are permitted. All fires must be out by 11:00pm.
14.	We love our trees. Please treat them kindly by not hanging or tying anything to them or abusing them in any manner.
15.	Please help conserve water. No car or RV washing, please. Write a review Sort by Most recent Most recent Most helpful Highest rating Lowest rating SoCal LD 3 reviews Â· 3 review votes Member 3 3 out of 5 stars 11/24/2020 We stayed for a week in November of 2020. We had to initially change our reservation to a little later as we were initially planning for the same time that Hurricane Eta came through. The staff was reasonable enough with the change but when contacting them over the phone for various questions it was hit or miss for getting someone that was pleasant versus unpleasant. We ended up having the same experience with people at the front desk. Most were pleasant and helpful, but they do seem to keep some... Read More We stayed for a week in November of 2020. We had to initially change our reservation to a little later as we were initially planning for the same time that Hurricane Eta came through. The staff was reasonable enough with the change but when contacting them over the phone for various questions it was hit or miss for getting someone that was pleasant versus unpleasant. We ended up having the same experience with people at the front desk. Most were pleasant and helpful, but they do seem to keep some around that just love being nasty to you, which really detracts from what could be a great park. As long as the park isn't full, the wifi is pretty good, but once the park fills up the wifi simply doesn't work and we had to resort to using our phones as individual hotspots instead of the camp wifi. There are times of the day when the aircraft noise from the airport and the navy base is near constant and this is a real pain to trying to enjoy your time here. I would be highly skeptical of the recommendations from the front office for things to do and services like cart and car rentals. It's pretty clear that the ones they recommend benefit them more than you. We followed their recommendations for renting a cart to drive around but had an impossible time trying to communicate with the vendor as they didn't speak English and were very reluctant to even talk to us. When it was dropped off they gave us no overview of the features, like where the gas tank was or even how to return it, so we assumed that as they dropped it off right at our site, they would pick it up the same way. Turns out that return procedure is VERY different and the front office people were quite nasty about making that known to us. I really like most of the amenities at this place in terms of good functionality and working order. The sites are generally clean and reasonably level to begin with, which is nice. What is lacking is a bit of space. Expect your neighbors to be right on top of you and we even had one put up a pop-up shade within inches of our rig into our site, which was more than a little annoying and rude. The beaches at the park are generally non-existent, even though they say they have two. Which is a real shame, because they are situated such that they could really offer some decent beach options. One is reasonably accessible, but has a no swimming sign. The other is only big enough for about 5 lounge chairs and filled with coral rocks at the waterline ranging from small pebble size to as large as golf balls and makes for a really unpleasant experience trying to enjoy the water. It just seems like they want you to see the water but don't touch it or go in it unless you have a boat. They have a boat launch and even a special bobcat tractor service to help move boats from parking areas to the launch. They also have a similar motorized tug service to help park 5th wheels in tight spots, which there are plenty. The park is a bit too far from town to be easy to access via walking or biking, but scooters, golf carts, and small cars. parking can be dicey in town, so be aware. Most of the food places in town, including some of the marquis places are mediocre at best and rather overpriced. This applies perfectly to the two closest restaurants to the park, Roostica Pizza and Hogfish, and just about every place we ate in town.  My general impression of Key West is that it's a giant tourist trap that doesn't deliver good value for your dollar. I would consider staying here again with lower expectations than I initially had, but I doubt I will return to Key West because it just isn't worth the hassle, over-priced everything, and throngs of generally rude people. We had to initially change our reservation to a little later as we were initially planning for the same time that Hurricane Eta came through. The staff was reasonable enough with the change but when contacting them over the phone for various questions it was hit or miss for getting someone that was pleasant versus unpleasant. We ended up having the same experience with people at the front desk. Most were pleasant and helpful, but they do seem to keep some... Read More We stayed for a week in November of 2020. We had to initially change our reservation to a little later as we were initially planning for the same time that Hurricane Eta came through. The staff was reasonable enough with the change but when contacting them over the phone for various questions it was hit or miss for getting someone that was pleasant versus unpleasant. We ended up having the same experience with people at the front desk. Most were pleasant and helpful, but they do seem to keep some around that just love being nasty to you, which really detracts from what could be a great park. As long as the park isn't full, the wifi is pretty good, but once the park fills up the wifi simply doesn't work and we had to resort to using our phones as individual hotspots instead of the camp wifi. There are times of the day when the aircraft noise from the airport and the navy base is near constant and this is a real pain to trying to enjoy your time here. I would be highly skeptical of the recommendations from the front office for things to do and services like cart and car rentals. It's pretty clear that the ones they recommend benefit them more than you. We followed their recommendations for renting a cart to drive around but had an impossible time trying to communicate with the vendor as they didn't speak English and were very reluctant to even talk to us. When it was dropped off they gave us no overview of the features, like where the gas tank was or even how to return it, so we assumed that as they dropped it off right at our site, they would pick it up the same way. Turns out that return procedure is VERY different and the front office people were quite nasty about making that known to us. I really like most of the amenities at this place in terms of good functionality and working order. The sites are generally clean and reasonably level to begin with, which is nice. What is lacking is a bit of space. Expect your neighbors to be right on top of you and we even had one put up a pop-up shade within inches of our rig into our site, which was more than a little annoying and rude. The beaches at the park are generally non-existent, even though they say they have two. Which is a real shame, because they are situated such that they could really offer some decent beach options. One is reasonably accessible, but has a no swimming sign. The other is only big enough for about 5 lounge chairs and filled with coral rocks at the waterline ranging from small pebble size to as large as golf balls and makes for a really unpleasant experience trying to enjoy the water. It just seems like they want you to see the water but don't touch it or go in it unless you have a boat. They have a boat launch and even a special bobcat tractor service to help move boats from parking areas to the launch. They also have a similar motorized tug service to help park 5th wheels in tight spots, which there are plenty. The park is a bit too far from town to be easy to access via walking or biking, but scooters, golf carts, and small cars. parking can be dicey in town, so be aware. Most of the food places in town, including some of the marquis places are mediocre at best and rather overpriced. This applies perfectly to the two closest restaurants to the park, Roostica Pizza and Hogfish, and just about every place we ate in town.  My general impression of Key West is that it's a giant tourist trap that doesn't deliver good value for your dollar. I would consider staying here again with lower expectations than I initially had, but I doubt I will return to Key West because it just isn't worth the hassle, over-priced everything, and throngs of generally rude people. What a full life I have lived. I began to realize that not even those closest to me know the full extent of my adventuresâ€”so I started writing them down. Itâ€™s become quite a project! But these stories represent more than just my life story. They are a permanent record of a way of life long since passedâ€”a time when people saw things from a different perspective, when things were done differently, and opportunities looked very different. Perhaps the reader will get to know, in some small way, some of the fine people Iâ€™ve knownâ€”my parents, my grandparents, and others who are now long gone. These stories are also a tribute to my family, especially my wife, and the many people Iâ€™ve met along the way. They have all helped shape the adventurous and fulfilling life Iâ€™ve been blessed to live. It has beenâ€”and still isâ€”a great life. I hope you enjoy reading these stories as much as Iâ€™ve enjoyed writing them. Iâ€™ve done my best to leave out anything inappropriate and to tell the truth as I remember itâ€”or as the world appears to me. Our First Camper, 1947 Elsie and I were married on June 25, 1947, and by late October, we were ready to hit the road in our homemade camper. It was just big enough for two peopleâ€”and not just any two people. You had to be very compatible and not too big. It was built to our own specificationsâ€”could you say it was custom-built? It was just high enough for me to stand upright. The bed ran crossways and was only 41 inches wide. That left just enough room at the back of the truck for a chest of drawers on one side, a built-in clothes closet on the other, and a small fold-down plywood table. A two-burner camp stove was fastened to the top of the chest of drawers. The whole camper measured eight feet long and seven feet, three inches wide. We were offâ€”from Saskatchewan to see the U.S.A.â€”and we had the whole winter to do it. Looking back now, Iâ€™m sure we looked exactly like what we were: a couple of country bumpkins. But that didnâ€™t slow us down. We were doing our thing, and our thing was to see as much of the U.S.A. as we could that winter of 1947â€“1948. At the time, Canadian law limited the amount of money you could take out of the country to $150 per personâ€”$300 total for the two of us for the entire winter, which we hoped would last four or five months. We hid a little money here and there in the camper, but we knew weâ€™d still be tight. We were both raised poor during the 1930s and knew how to get by on very little. We brought a bag of potatoesâ€”but those froze before we even got out of Canada. We didnâ€™t throw them away right away, but eventually, foam started coming out of their eyes, and we had to admit they were done for. Elsie canned a few apples we bought cheap in Illinois as we kept on moving. Of course, we never ate out, and we only visited things that were free. We traveled from Winnipeg to Chicago, to New York City, Washington, D.C., and Miamiâ€”then finally arrived in Key West on New Yearâ€™s Day, 1948. It cost $1.00 per day to stay at Mastic Trailer Park on United Street. That gave us a parking spot and use of the toilets and showers. While laying on the beach, we heard about a new thing called a credit card. I wrote to our Esso dealer in Sylvania, Saskatchewan, asking for one, and he sent me his. After that, we were in cloverâ€”we brazenly charged food, gasoline, even cash. After a month in Key West, we hit the road againâ€”New Orleans, Los Angeles, up the West Coast through Oregon and Washington, then back east through Montana and into Regina. We made it home to Sylvania by late March. It was a great tripâ€”one weâ€™d never forget. We made a complete circle of the U.S.A. and spent less than $700 total. That covered food, gas, camping, and everything else for four and a half months. Back home, we took the camper shell off the truck and got back to work. We spent that summer keeping bees and making honeyâ€”trying to earn enough money to do it all over again the next fall.
